message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including weight loss, itchy rash, and palpable lymph nodes, suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of this type of cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of an itchy rash, weight loss, palpable lymph nodes, and neoplastic cells on skin biopsy are consistent with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The peripheral smear is most likely to show CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei, which are characteristic of T-cell lymphomas. Giant cells with bilobed nuclei and erythrocytes with basophilic nuclear remnants are associated with viral infections, and myeloblasts with azurophilic granules are seen in acute myeloid leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy of a skin lesion suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), specifically mycosis fungoides. CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of CTCL and can be seen on a peripheral blood smear. The other options are not associated with CTCL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The most common cell type in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) and the biopsy confirms it. CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of CTCL and are most likely to be seen on peripheral blood smear in this patient. Giant cells with bilobed nuclei are seen in Hodgkin lymphoma, erythrocytes with basophilic nuclear remnants are seen in megaloblastic anemia, and myeloblasts with azurophilic granules are seen in acute myeloid leukemia, none of which are likely diagnoses in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The multiple erythematous plaques and palpable lymph nodes suggest lymphoma, specifically cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Therefore, the most likely finding on peripheral blood smear is CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei, which is characteristic of this type of lymphoma. Option A and B suggest different types of leukocytes and are not associated with lymphoma. Option D suggests a myeloid disorder, not a lymphoid disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is characterized by proliferation of T-cells with cerebriform nuclei. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesions and lymph nodes suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), and among the options, only CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of this lymphoma. Giant cells with bilobed nuclei are seen in Hodgkin lymphoma, erythrocytes with basophilic nuclear remnants are seen in megaloblastic anemia, and myeloblasts with azurophilic granules are seen in acute myeloid leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and skin lesion biopsy suggest a diagnosis of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is characterized by the presence of CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is characterized by the presence of CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral blood smear. The other options are not associated with this condition.
